text: @Regrann from @gabriele_corno -  Lenticular clouds over Fuji, Japan......#Awesome #amazing #cool #colors #magic #ma… http://t.co/yziiWCZ2V5
image_text:
1. None
2. Photo
3. The image is a photo of a mountain with a series of unique cloud formations above it, resembling stacked layers. There are no characters in this picture. The mountain, capped with snow, stands prominently in the background, while the foreground appears to be a flat landscape, possibly a plain or a frozen body of water. The cloud formations, known as lenticular clouds, are often mistaken for UFOs due to their saucer-like shape. These clouds typically form at high altitudes and are aligned perpendicular to the wind direction. This picture likely captures the natural beauty and phenomena associated with mountainous regions, emphasizing the interaction between the earth's surface and the atmosphere.
4. None

[Text] Astronomers love clouds. Well, actually a lot of us hate clouds, but a lot of us are fascinated by meteorology, and clouds in particular. I love 'em all, from cumulonimbus to mammatus. But there's something about the bizarre lenticular clouds-- lens-shaped beasties that form downwind from

[Title] Mesmerizing footage shows rare cloud formation over Mount Fuji: "Magic"
[Text] Jan 04, 2024 at 1:04 PM EST By Soo Kim SEO Reporter An astonishing display of lenticular clouds was seen on Honshu, Japan's largest and most populous island. The rare sighting took place in the...
[Source] https://www.newsweek.com/timelapse-rare-lenticular-clouds-mount-fuji-japan-1857872)
[Title] Fact Check: This morphed image of Mount Fuji clouds the truth
[Text] Claim Lenticular clouds over Mount Fuji in Japan. Fact This is a photoshopped picture. The actual image was taken by one Raymond R Carr in 2005. In the actual image, only one layer of lenticular cloud can be seen. The other layers have been digitally added in the viral image. Chayan Kundu New Delhi, UPDATED: Nov 23, 2021 22:21 IST
[Source] https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/fact-check-this-morphed-image-of-mount-fuji-clouds-the-truth-1880072-2021-11-23)
[Title] Fact Check: This morphed image of Mount Fuji clouds the truth
[Text] India Today Anti Fake News War Room (AFWA) has found that this is a photoshopped picture. The actual image was taken by one Raymond R Carr in 2005. In the actual image, only one layer of lenticular cloud can be seen. The other layers have been digitally added in the viral image. AFWA probe
[Source] https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/fact-check-this-morphed-image-of-mount-fuji-clouds-the-truth-1880072-2021-11-23)
[Title] Mesmerizing Footage Shows Rare Cloud Formation Over Mount ... - Newsweek
[Text] Jan 04, 2024 at 1:04 PM EST By Soo Kim SEO Reporter An astonishing display of lenticular clouds was seen on Honshu, Japan's largest and most populous island. The rare sighting took place in...
[Source] https://www.newsweek.com/timelapse-rare-lenticular-clouds-mount-fuji-japan-1857872)
[Title] Mesmerizing footage shows rare cloud formation over Mount Fuji: "Magic"
[Text] Jan 04, 2024 at 1:04 PM EST By Soo Kim SEO Reporter An astonishing display of lenticular clouds was seen on Honshu, Japan's largest and most populous island. The rare sighting took place in the...
[Source] https://www.newsweek.com/timelapse-rare-lenticular-clouds-mount-fuji-japan-1857872)
[Title] Fact Check: This morphed image of Mount Fuji clouds the truth
[Text] AFWA probe Using reverse image search, we found the original picture, which was posted by one Raymond R Carr on his Flickr account on March 15, 2005. The caption with the image reads, "Just an interesting cloud formation that formed over Fujijama looks a little like the hats some rice farmers use."
[Source] https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/fact-check-this-morphed-image-of-mount-fuji-clouds-the-truth-1880072-2021-11-23)

explain:
The knowledge graphs (KGs) provide a structured representation of the information from both the text and the image. The first KG, derived from the text, suggests that there are lenticular clouds located over Mount Fuji in Japan, which is a plausible scenario. The second KG, derived from the image, also identifies lenticular clouds positioned above a mountain and mentions the possibility of these clouds being mistaken for UFOs, which is a common misperception due to their shape.

However, the external resources provide critical information that challenges the authenticity of the image. Multiple sources, including a fact-check article from India Today, indicate that the image in question is photoshopped and that the original image taken by Raymond R Carr in 2005 only showed one layer of lenticular clouds, not multiple stacked layers as seen in the viral image. This discrepancy between the actual event and the representation in the image is a clear indication of misinformation.

Given the evidence from the external resources, which are deemed trustworthy, it is apparent that the image has been digitally altered to exaggerate the appearance of the lenticular clouds. Therefore, despite the initial KG analysis not revealing inconsistencies, the external verification has provided sufficient grounds to classify the news article as containing misinformation.

```python
]
```

explain:
The knowledge graphs (KGs) provide structured information about the entities and relationships within the text and image of the news post. The first KG derived from the text part of the news indicates a relationship between Lenticular Clouds and Mount Fuji, which is a plausible association as lenticular clouds can form above mountains. The second KG derived from the image suggests that lenticular clouds are depicted above a mount and can be mistaken for UFOs, which is consistent with the nature of lenticular clouds as they are known for their saucer-like appearance.

However, the external resources provide crucial information that casts doubt on the authenticity of the image associated with the news post. Multiple sources, including Snopes.com and India Today's Anti Fake News War Room (AFWA), indicate that images of lenticular clouds over Mount Fuji have been digitally altered in the past, with additional layers of clouds being added to the original photograph taken by Raymond R Carr in 2005. This suggests that the image in question could potentially be one of those altered images, especially since the external resources repeatedly mention the existence of photoshopped pictures of Mount Fuji with lenticular clouds.

Given the information from the external resources, which are considered trustworthy, it appears that the image associated with the news post may indeed contain misinformation due to digital alteration. Therefore, despite the initial KG analysis not indicating any discrepancies, the external evidence strongly suggests that the image is not authentic and has been manipulated.

Based on the external resources provided, which indicate that the image has been photoshopped, the final decision is that the news article contains misinformation.
